resources.string:
This is a recovery progress indicator calculated by Chally’s own algorithm.

It accumulates scores based on real recovery flow, reflecting challenge duration, reset frequency, and activities. Various recovery effects are unlocked step-by-step as your score increases.

Even if there are resets, the traces of recovery do not disappear.
Your transformation continues to be recorded amid pauses and repetitions.
You paused before the habit took over. Change has begun.
You\'re starting to notice impulses instead of being led by them.
Irritability or restlessness may appear — signs of your brain adjusting.
You break the automatic pattern. A day without it feels possible.
Physical or emotional discomfort surfaces, then fades. You\'re adapting.
Your concentration returns in small moments. Things feel clearer.
Mood swings reduce and calm begins to linger longer.
You start to trust your willpower and feel more in control.
Small routines strengthen, and setbacks no longer feel like the end.
You interact more freely without shame or hiding.
Your body and mind sync again. Sleep, digestion, and mood improve.
Others notice your energy, presence, and change.
You\'re no longer resisting, but living. It\'s not a fight — it\'s your state.
The habit no longer defines you. You\'re living fully, on your own terms.
Blood pressure and pulse stabilize, and warmth returns to your hands and feet.
Carbon monoxide exits and oxygen saturation returns to normal.
As stimulation drops, withdrawal symptoms like anxiety, restlessness, and reduced focus appear — a sign of change.
Smell and taste return, and meals and air feel new.
Strong cravings arise but are short-lived. They soon pass.
Emotional swings and irritability lessen as the brain begins to calm down.
Bronchial tubes relax, breathing feels easier, and lungs feel more open.
Sleep deepens, coughing decreases, and fatigue gradually fades.
Focus, stamina, and motivation return, and daily life starts to flow smoothly.
Breathing becomes easier and energy increases. You feel lighter than before smoking.
Functions like appetite, blood circulation, and digestion stabilize.
Your skin tone brightens, odors disappear, and people respond differently.
Risk of cardiovascular disease is reduced by half.
Lung and circulatory functions resemble those of a non-smoker, confirming your decision.
A smoke-free life becomes natural, and you consciously embrace a healthier lifestyle.
By resisting the sudden urge, you\'ve already crossed the first turning point.
A subtle shift in mood appears. Your inner energy is starting to awaken.
Your emotions rise and fall. A strange sense of confusion begins.
Habits are strong and temptations clear. But this struggle is part of meaningful recovery.
Progress may feel slow and motivation low—your brain is adjusting to life without stimulation.
Explicit scenes no longer feel as intense. Your brain is regaining balance.
Your thoughts become clearer and words flow more naturally. Communication improves.
Dulled feelings come back to life, and emotional expression feels more natural.
The way people see you changes. Your eyes brighten and confidence grows.
You find yourself absorbed even in small tasks, losing track of time in focus.
Work, study, and relationships begin to flow more naturally again.
You no longer lie awake at night, and sleep quality noticeably improves.
You begin to feel opportunities arriving, and your energy spreads outward.
You no longer care about others\' opinions. Your center becomes solid and clear.
You choose direction over desire. You are no longer swayed.
Alcohol begins to break down, and your body starts to cleanse.
Your eyes become clearer, facial swelling decreases, and fatigue slightly reduces.
Insomnia, anxiety, and irritability arise, revealing signs of alcohol dependence.
Thoughts of drinking come and go. It\'s a time requiring avoidance and coping skills.
You experience the first moment of waking up feeling light and refreshed.
Daily life feels more spacious without alcohol, accompanied by slight emptiness or restlessness.
Successfully exercising self-control, your self-esteem begins to recover.
Irritability and mood swings decrease, and you feel much calmer than before.
You’re able to concentrate even for short periods, and mental clarity returns.
You can express yourself more naturally and healthily in relationships.
Deep, stable sleep becomes regular, increasing the density of your vitality.
Your skin brightens, internal organ fatigue decreases, and overall condition improves significantly.
The benefits of an alcohol-free life become clear, and you no longer wish to go back.
Liver health, blood pressure, and immunity normalize across the board.
You find joy and ease without alcohol, and gain the strength to lead your life by choice.
Today you paused instead of playing — a true progress point, not a reset, is recorded.
The time once spent on games now feels empty, but this space is where recovery begins.
Reality may feel dull without stimulation. But your brain is adapting.
You start to rethink your daily routine away from game-centered habits.
Fantasies about gaming may resurface. But you\'re building strength to overcome them.
You begin to focus more on real-life activities, and reactions to stimulation decrease.
The sense of “fun” starts to come back even in real life.
You get sleepy naturally at night, and mornings feel less heavy.
Conversations with others become easier, and you gain interest in topics beyond games.
You grow the ability to decide what to do and how to spend your time.
Game-related thoughts fade, and impulses feel less intense than before.
You feel a sense of reward from small achievements and become more responsive to real feedback.
Games may now seem boring or repetitive. Your life is gaining new focus.
You can focus for long periods without exhaustion and turn that energy into real-life outcomes.
Now, you are the main character playing life itself — in control of choices and flow.
The moment you stop endless scrolling, your time begins to come back to life.
Autoplay ends, and a day without background noise passes by.
When unconscious browsing stops, you may feel emptiness for the first time.
Your brain, accustomed to fast and strong stimuli, slowly begins to adapt.
Eating or resting without videos feels awkward. Your brain is recovering space.
Resistance to quiet decreases, and time for self-reflection grows.
Distractions lessen, and the time you stay focused on one task gradually increases.
You fall asleep without videos, and your sleep quality improves.
Time no longer drags, and you begin to manage your schedule on your own.
Your eyes shift from the screen to people, scenery, books, and objects.
You begin to hear your inner voice again, and your thoughts deepen.
Your dependence on short, fast videos significantly decreases.
You adapt to the pace and rhythm of reality, and even small things don\'t feel boring.
Your time is now your own, and you have gained the power to choose information and stimulation.
No longer swayed by recommendation algorithms, you lead the flow of your life yourself.
The moment your fingers stop, your gaze begins to turn inward instead of outward.
Push notifications decrease, and the digital noise of the day fades.
The habit of opening apps without thinking stops, and your mind briefly goes blank.
The habit of comparing with others fades, and your focus returns to your own life.
Without constant distraction, you begin to focus even on small things.
You become less sensitive to others\' reactions and start prioritizing your own emotions.
Being alone no longer feels awkward — instead, it brings peace of mind.
Anxiety and overstimulation decrease, and emotional ups and downs start to level out.
Instead of other people\'s feeds, your focus shifts to your own thoughts, which deepen.
You free yourself from comments, likes, and social pressure, and feel mentally lighter.
Relationships in the real world — not virtual ones — start to feel more meaningful.
You begin to see yourself through your own standards, not through others\'.
Even if you open the app, you lose interest quickly and use it only when necessary.
You stop being swept away by the feed and start selectively consuming what you need.
You become the center of your own life — no longer defined by others, free from the digital world.
As you reduce gluten intake, digestive discomfort lessens and your body begins to feel lighter.
You feel less bloated, and fullness is comfortably maintained.
Bowel movements become more regular, and your gut rhythm gradually returns.
Swelling in your face or limbs visibly decreases.
You begin to break free from carb addiction and feel fewer urges to overeat.
You notice a reduction in skin issues like redness, blemishes, or breakouts.
Post-meal drowsiness fades, and your energy for activity improves.
Your mind clears, and you start to regain focus and mental clarity.
Gut pain, gas, and bloating are significantly reduced.
Even meals based on protein and vegetables provide fullness and satisfaction.
Your weight begins to adjust naturally, and your abdomen starts to slim down.
Your body feels lighter overall, and fatigue no longer builds up easily.
A gluten-free diet becomes your new norm, and your body maintains a sense of balance.
Frequent colds and allergic reactions decrease, and you feel healthier overall.
Internal inflammation and discomfort disappear, improving both your appearance and vitality.
When you resist one temptation, the seed of self-control begins to grow.
You may feel anxious thinking about missed chances, but that\'s the first sign of recovery.
You waver between regret and impulse, but the most important thing is that you didn\'t go back.
Even amidst dopamine waves, you start to see the value of real life.
Temptation arises often, but you\'re learning to recognize and avoid its patterns.
Emotional ups and downs decrease, and rational judgment gradually returns.
You become aware of your repeated patterns and start to feel the need for change.
Your dulled sense of money begins to return little by little.
Your mind begins to focus more on real plans and responsibilities than virtual betting.
Compulsive urges decrease, and peaceful feelings become more common than tension.
The ability to resist impulses begins to build in a structured way.
You gain a strong will to organize your finances, relationships, and emotions.
You begin to feel that a life without gambling isn\'t so bad after all.
The frequent habit disappears, and impulses no longer interfere with your daily life.
The image of betting no longer feels appealing — you experience true freedom.
A small decision marks the beginning of recovery. Even one day of stopping makes you different already.
Withdrawal symptoms may cause anxiety or restlessness, but they\'re signs that your brain is healing.
Cravings may hit hard, but every moment you resist, your self-control grows.
You begin to build the ability to avoid triggers and harmful habits.
You may feel extremely drained and powerless, but this is your brain rebalancing itself.
Mood swings can be intense, but you grow in your ability to recognize and accept emotions.
Appetite, sleep, and organ functions gradually return to normal.
The fog around memory and thinking starts to lift.
Social withdrawal lessens, and natural interaction with others begins again.
You become less overwhelmed by emotions like anger, sadness, or depression.
Your self-esteem and self-image begin to take shape again.
Moments of addiction now feel distant and unfamiliar.
You gain confidence in your ability to control yourself.
You start to feel like a completely different person than before.
The traces of addiction disappear, and you begin to live in complete freedom and peace.
When you start quitting caffeine, temporary headaches or fatigue may occur.
Your body tries to adapt to less stimulation, and reduced focus may be felt.
Feelings of anxiety and restlessness decrease, and your mind begins to calm.
It takes less time to fall asleep, and sleep quality begins to improve.
Your body starts to distinguish between real fatigue and artificial alertness.
You begin to feel a steady energy flow even without caffeine.
Heartburn, excess acid, and digestive discomfort begin to ease.
Irritability, anxiety, and sensitivity decrease, and emotional swings become more stable.
The habit of acting in sync with caffeine timing begins to fade.
You get used to maintaining steady energy rather than short bursts of speed.
Your brain stays alert and focused without caffeine.
Nighttime awakenings lessen, and deep sleep comes more naturally.
Your stomach no longer feels irritated on an empty stomach, and your day starts in comfort.
Your sleep-wake cycle aligns more closely with your body\'s natural rhythm.
You no longer feel like you need caffeine to function.
Preparing a meal at home slows down the pace of eating.
Food tastes less salty, and swelling in your body begins to decrease.
With less fried and saturated fat, your stomach feels less bloated.
You become more aware of food expenses, and your spending habits start to shift.
Mindless scrolling through delivery apps begins to fade.
Stomach discomfort decreases, and bowel movements become easier.
You become more aware of taste and texture in your food.
Meal times and portions start to become more consistent.
You grow accustomed to homemade meals over processed foods.
A diet rich in protein and vegetables becomes your new normal.
You begin to enjoy flavors without needing strong stimulation.
Weight begins to drop gradually, even without strict dieting.
Eating becomes a more relaxed experience, offering mental calm.
You start to feel how meals directly affect your physical condition.
You find you can live a fully satisfying life without eating out.
The simple act of resisting a purchase marks the beginning of self-control.
You no longer get swayed by shopping alerts or discount messages.
You become aware of the exact moment when shopping urges arise.
Instead of unnecessary spending, you begin to value simplicity and decluttering.
You start distancing yourself from unneeded items by clearing your online shopping cart.
Emotion-driven purchases decrease, and you spend only on what you truly need.
You feel less anxious when checking your bank balance.
You focus more on using and experiencing things rather than owning them.
The habit of shopping out of boredom slowly disappears.
Instead of rushing to buy, you begin to enjoy the process of choosing.
You feel emotionally full even without acquiring new things.
You begin to spend based on your own judgment, not external influence.
Instead of buying things, you want to learn, grow, and enrich yourself.
You naturally realize that shopping is no longer the center of your life.
Your true spending begins — free from emotions, marketing, and habits.
The moment you stop a swear word from coming out, the seed of self-control is planted.
You gain a brief moment to pause and reflect before expressing emotions.
Even when irritated, you begin to manage your reactions instead of lashing out.
You start paying attention to how words come out of your mouth.
You begin to find other ways to express your emotions.
Your tone softens, and the frequency of conflict in conversations decreases.
Instead of releasing emotions through language, you begin to regulate them.
Unnecessary arguments decrease, making interactions with others smoother.
You start to objectively observe your speech habits and desire to improve them.
Respectful expressions toward yourself and others become your new habit.
You come to deeply understand the power and impact of a single word.
As you distance yourself from verbal aggression, your mind becomes much more stable.
You develop more vocabulary to express emotions honestly and healthily.
Your tone and word choice begin to reflect sophistication and dignity.
Now, you can speak firmly and warmly without swearing at all.
You consciously begin to put down your smartphone that your hands reached for unconsciously.
You start to endure short idle moments without your phone.
You stop reacting instantly to push notifications and respond with calm.
You become aware of and able to stop endless scrolling on SNS or YouTube.
A morning routine without your smartphone begins to take shape.
Without information overload, your mind feels noticeably lighter.
Reducing smartphone use before bed leads to deeper sleep.
You look at your phone less during conversations, enhancing real connection.
You gain more time to immerse deeply in tasks.
You develop immunity to app temptations and content overload.
More time spent daydreaming, walking, or reflecting helps restore creativity.
You no longer feel bored without your phone and begin to feel free.
You become more engaged in offline hobbies, relationships, and experiences.
Scattered attention diminishes, and daily life feels more grounded.
You begin to use your smartphone only when it is truly necessary—as a tool.
